top_comment.author: rurutu M

comments.text:
+Lmar daggerwolf it had five movies leading up to it and explained where 
some of its secondary characters were coming from and why, therefore it 
does have not one but many character arcs that are continued in the Phase 2 
movies.
Admittedly if you watch The Avengers by itself then it feels like mindless 
fun but the main point of a cinematic Universe is how all of the individual 
stories tell one much bigger story that eventually leads up to one 
conclusion.
If you don't like it that's fine but you'll probably have to watch like 10 
movies in order to get everything that happens in Avengers 2 (I strongly 
suggest the first Thor, Iron Man and both Captain America movies if you 
wanna narrow it down).

comments.text:
+KabbalahSherry FF has been the summer movie of my 20s. It's just fun, like 
tons of other movies. I don't get the hate from Transformers, or TMNT too.

are, always been, always will. We are NOT the people bringing money to the

You should watch the FF series, or at least the last 3 ones. 4, 5, 6.

comments.text:
+KabbalahSherry It's all in the same universe and yes they all connect 
together. You could watch 1, 2 and 3 separately but 4, 5 and 6 is what 
links them all together. Tokyo Drift was originally going to be a separate 
movie but than they decided to go back to the original story with 4. In the 
end they made all the films link together by the time we reach 7.

comments.text:
1 to 3 is purely racing with a little bit of action. 4 to 6 is mostly 
action with some racing (Same as what you see in this trailer)

miss 2 Fast 2 Furious and still understand the story.

comments.text:
I'm unsubscribing. Grace you look to much at cinema from a business 
perspective rather than being a consumer and the quality of the product. 
This blinds your judgement cause in a lot of your reviews you do not 
actually talk about the film or trailer itself as much as appropriate. U 
look at box office earnings, acting careers and (particularly if its a 
marvel movie) what they are going to do next(ie a sequel/franchise). Yes 
this is something to take into consideration but you over emphasise these 
things which shouldn't be involved in your judgement. Your to absorbed by 
the business side of Hollywood. It's annoying. And seriously the best 
trailer you have ever seen that's absurd. I know it's your opinion and 
that's not the problem. How u formulate ur opinion is the problem. And I 
was once a regular viewer of urs but this is too much

comments.text:
+Waseem Amin Tokyo drift comes after fast 6 even though it wasn't released 
in that order. Han goes to tokyo after number 6 because of what happened. 
Then Jason Statham is hunting everyone from number 6 which is why he kills 
him in the trailer. Hence number 7 trailer Chris Bridges says 'we are being 
hunted'. Maybe you should watch them in the correct order it might help. 1, 
2, 4, 5, 6, tokyo drift, 7. Then you might have a better understanding of 
the franchise.

top_comment.text:
Furious 7 isn't exactly James Wan's first action flick, ya'know. Shortly 
after Saw, he directed Death Sentence, starring Kevin Bacon. I think it's 
considered more of a drama, but there's still loads of action & violence 
throughout. -Nicely shot, & stylishly choreographed too -especially during 
this 1 action sequence in a parking-garage in which the camera just keeps 
on rolling for what feels like an eternity before finally cutting to a new 
shot) -Having seen "Death Sentence, I've got a strong feeling that Wan's 
F&F movie will be just as fun as 5 & 6 were﻿
top_comment.author: Andrew Forsleff

comments.text:
lol, & when exactly did I claim "Death Sentence" was perfect ? The only 
positives I gave were that it was "Nicely shot, & stylishly choreographed", 
and that basically James Wan would make a great F&F director because that 
series isn't exactly oscar-material either now is it, Lancaster? :) Peace! 
oh, & may the rest of your days be filled with happiness

I don't have friends, I got family.
